div.p: Landgrave Philipp etc. a small piece of jewelry made of rubies and pearls.
Elector Palatine Friedrich etc. a chain with a pendant, containing an almandine and a diamond.
Elector of Saxony etc. a chain, with a small piece of jewelry containing a diamond and three rubies.
Duke Wolfgang etc. a necklace made of pearls, rubies, diamonds, and emeralds with a diamond cross.
The princes of Weimar etc. a small piece of jewelry made of diamonds, rubies, and emeralds.
Duke Christoph etc. two chains, the smaller of which has a ruby cross with pearls.
Margrave Karl etc. a small piece of jewelry with a topaz and garnets.
Bishop of Strasbourg a double goblet with his coat of arms. The government of Ensisheim a double gilded drinking vessel with the royal coat of arms.
Count Georg of Helfenstein etc. a gilded double drinking vessel with his coat of arms.
The city of Strasbourg a gilded covered drinking vessel with the city coat of arms.
The city of Basel a gilded covered drinking vessel with the city coat of arms.
Mülhausen a silver covered cup with gilded clothing and their coat of arms on the lid.
Colmar 50 gold guilders. Schlettstadt 26 gold guilders.
Keisersberg 12 crowns. Durkheim 6 crowns.
Münster 9 gold guilders and 4 crowns.
Breisach a gilded drinking vessel shaped like a pear with their coat of arms on the lid.
The city of Montbéliard a double gilded drinking vessel with the city coat of arms.
The region of Montbéliard a silver covered cup, on which is a naked little man with a mace; inside were 100 crowns.
Blamont a silver double drinking vessel with gilded clothing.
The region of Blamont a covered gilded cup, on the lid a little child with a bird.
Neuenburg office a high double gilded goblet with the city coat of arms.
Riquewihr and Harburg a double gilded drinking vessel or goblet, containing 100 gold guilders.

There are many other gifts that I have not been able to see, such as those from the noblemen and the lord of Ribeaupierre, which is said to be a goblet set with precious stones, valued at 1100 guilders.
The lords of Schaffhausen and Zurich two gold penny coins with their coats of arms and bailiwicks engraved, valued at 100 guilders.

To the fifteen preachers of both dominions Riquewihr and Harburg was given a large Zurich Bible covered with green velvet and gilded, with silver clasps and hinges, also gilded; cost 45 guilders. In return, the preachers were honored with fifty guilders. Hęc est munificentia principis in foemino genere, quę se obtulit omnem operam adhibiturum, ut Christi verbum inter tot guerras promoveatur. Amen etc.
"Gift for my gracious prince and lord's wedding."
